title: Comparison of waste combustion and waste electrolysis - A systems analysis
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040397, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Holtzapple, Mark T.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Texas A&M Univ.', 'location': 'College Station, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'f693e856184c4d3eb554549fa8acb8d3'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900040397, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Little, Frank E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Texas A & M University', 'location': 'College Station, United States'}}, 'id': '185914aafea3432ab2023bf37ba30ae6'}]
abstract: A steady state model of a closed environmental system has been developed which includes higher plant growth for food production, and is designed to allow wastes to be combusted or electrolyzed. The stoichiometric equations have been developed to evaluate various trash compositions, food items (both stored and produced), metabolic rates, and crew sizes. The advantages of waste electrolysis versus combustion are: (1) oxygen is not required (which reduces the load on the oxygen producing system); (2) the CO2 and H2 products are produced in pure form (reducing the load on the separators); and (3) nitrogen is converted to nitrate (which is directly usable by plants). Weight tradeoff studies performed using this model have shown that waste electrolysis reduces the life support weight of a 4-person crew by 1000 to 2000 kg.

title: The use of models to predict potential contamination aboard orbital vehicles
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040404, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Boraas, Martin E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Wisconsin Univ.', 'location': 'Milwaukee, WI, United States'}}, 'id': '4a4d9b8bab454202b2e41593c7e657da'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900040404, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Seale, Dianne B.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Wisconsin, University', 'location': 'Milwaukee, United States'}}, 'id': 'bc57e8cfef3e4b288393b231ca4084d3'}]
abstract: A model of fungal growth on air-exposed, nonnutritive solid surfaces, developed for utilization aboard orbital vehicles is presented. A unique feature of this testable model is that the development of a fungal mycelium can facilitate its own growth by condensation of water vapor from its environment directly onto fungal hyphae. The fungal growth rate is limited by the rate of supply of volatile nutrients and fungal biomass is limited by either the supply of nonvolatile nutrients or by metabolic loss processes. The model discussed is structurally simple, but its dynamics can be quite complex. Biofilm accumulation can vary from a simple linear increase to sustained exponential growth, depending on the values of the environmental variable and model parameters. The results of the model are consistent with data from aquatic biofilm studies, insofar as the two types of systems are comparable. It is shown that the model presented is experimentally testable and provides a platform for the interpretation of observational data that may be directly relevant to the question of growth of organisms aboard the proposed Space Station.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

abstract: The water reclamation subsystems currently being evaluated for the Space Shuttle Freedom are briefly reviewed with emphasis on a waste water management system capable of processing wastes containing high concentrations of organic/inorganic materials. The process combines low temperature/pressure to vaporize water with high temperature catalytic oxidation to decompose volatile organics. The reclaimed water is of potable quality and has high potential for maintenance under sterile conditions. Results from preliminary experiments and modifications in process and equipment required to control reliability and repeatability of system operation are presented.

title: Design concepts for the Centrifuge Facility Life Sciences Glovebox
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040436, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Sun, Sidney C.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '3b4b5d94d07f4147b902c7f9cf681ae5'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900040436, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Horkachuck, Michael J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '4d3c67299eef40cb91913871a591a73f'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900040436, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mckeown, Kellie A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '445e7a98834b4617ac590533f0e9cece'}]
abstract: The Life Sciences Glovebox will provide the bioisolated environment to support on-orbit operations involving non-human live specimens and samples for human life sceinces experiments. It will be part of the Centrifuge Facility, in which animal and plant specimens are housed in bioisolated Habitat modules and transported to the Glovebox as part of the experiment protocols supported by the crew. At the Glovebox, up to two crew members and two habitat modules must be accommodated to provide flexibility and support optimal operations. This paper will present several innovative design concepts that attempt to satisfy the basic Glovebox requirements. These concepts were evaluated for ergonomics and ease of operations using computer modeling and full-scale mockups. The more promising ideas were presented to scientists and astronauts for their evaluation. Their comments, and the results from other evaluations are presented. Based on the evaluations, the authors recommend designs and features that will help optimize crew performance and facilitate science accommodations, and specify problem areas that require further study.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The Life Sciences Glovebox will provide the bioisolated environment to support on-orbit operations involving non-human live specimens and samples for human life sceinces experiments . Up to two crew members and two habitat modules must be accommodated to provide flexibility and support optimal operations .

title: Biofilm formation and control in a simulated spacecraft water system - Interim results
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040452, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Schultz, John R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Krug International', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'aeb0486b714949d6b8c436703c92042a'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900040452, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Taylor, Robert D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Krug International', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': '5fb264b8cb494f7fb1de5626d4f6093f'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900040452, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Flanagan, David T.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Krug International', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': '78ea4526df464ad29d51f6cfd33f2099'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19900040452, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Gibbons, Randall E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Krug International', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'b52df9043bc841ba8bb3bbfeb13f9d1f'}, {'sequence': 4, 'submissionId': 19900040452, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Brown, Harlan D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Krug International Corp.', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'ba378e44195f4de7b80299a816f88b97'}, {'sequence': 5, 'submissionId': 19900040452, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Sauer, Richard L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Johnson Space Center', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': '0bb6f8382b194c6a88e45d8a2f5a2908'}]
abstract: The ability of iodine to control microbial contamination and biofilm formation in spacecraft water distribution systems is studied using two stainless steel water subsystems. One subsystem has an iodine level of 2.5 mg/L maintained by an iodinated ion-exchange resin. The other subsystem has no iodine added. Stainless steel coupons are removed from each system to monitor biofilm formation. Results from the first six months of operation indicate that 2.5 mg/L of iodine has limited the number of viable bacteria that can be recovered from the iodinated subsystem. Epifluorescence microscopy of the coupons taken from this subsystem, however, indicates some evidence of microbial colonization after 15 weeks of operation. Numerous bacteria have been continually removed from both the water samples and the coupons taken from the noniodinated subsystem after only 3 weeks of operation.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The ability of iodine to control microbial contamination and biofilm formation in spacecraft water distribution systems is studied using two stainless steel water subsystems . One subsystem has an iodine level of 2.5 mg/L maintained by an iodinated ion-exchange resin . The other subsystem has no iodine added .

title: Phase III integrated water recovery testing at MSFC - Design, plans, and protocols
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040461, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Bagdigian, Robert M.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Marshall Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Huntsville, AL, United States'}}, 'id': '8d05e70d59104bf7b686d6bd49fa2f71'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900040461, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Whitman, Gerald A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Boeing Aerospace Co.', 'location': 'Seattle, WA, United States'}}, 'id': 'f3f3215910364284a21596a41cb30840'}]
abstract: A series of tests is being conducted at the NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) to evaluate the performance of a closed-loop water recovery system. Testing will be conducted at various levels of integration and loop-closure, culminating in complete closure of the water system with man-in-the-loop. This paper summarizes the test goals and objectives as well as the system design, plans, and protocols which have been established.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A series of tests is being conducted at the NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) to evaluate the performance of a closed-loop water recovery system . Testing will be conducted at various levels of integration and loop-closure, culminating in complete closure of the water system with man-in-the-loop .

title: Carbon use efficiency in optimal environments
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040478, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Bugbee, Bruce'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Utah State University', 'location': 'Logan, United States'}}, 'id': '12c367f12bf547f0bfdceb3345a6d4ef'}]
abstract: The short- and long-term effects of environmental changes on plant productivity are studied using a model in which yield is determined by four factors: absorption of photosynthetic photon flux, photosynthetic efficiency, respiratory carbon use efficiency, and harvest index. The characteristics of the model are reviewed. Emphasis is given to the relationship between carbon use efficiency and yield. The biochemical pathways resulting in CO2 efflux are examined, including photorespiration, cyanide-resistant respiration, and dark respiration. The possibility of measuring photosynthesis and respiration in a CELSS is discussed.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The short- and long-term effects of environmental changes on plant productivity are studied using a model in which yield is determined by four factors . Emphasis is given to the relationship between carbon use efficiency and yield . The biochemical pathways resulting in CO2 efflux are examined, including photorespiration, cyanide-resistant respiration, and dark respiration .

title: Atmosphere control for plant growth flight experiments
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900040491, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Powell, Ferolyn T.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Life Systems, Inc.', 'location': 'Cleveland, OH, United States'}}, 'id': '4b5a5763c96f437387519383843ff16c'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900040491, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Sudar, Martin'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Life Systems, Inc.', 'location': 'Cleveland, OH, United States'}}, 'id': 'fd6b79d65bfc46eb82ef5bcfe2b3fc63'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900040491, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Timm, Marc'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Life Systems, Inc.', 'location': 'Cleveland, OH, United States'}}, 'id': 'cca8637e6a364de08c35e5735ddd1c93'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19900040491, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Yost, Bruce'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Bionetics Corp.', 'location': 'Cocoa Beach, FL, United States'}}, 'id': 'c1cedce27c474b45bb5f68374132253d'}]
abstract: An atmosphere exchange system (AES) has been designed to provide a conditioned atmosphere supply to plant specimens in flight without incurring the large weight and volume associated with bottled gases. The paper examines the atmosphere filter cartridge (AFC) designed to remove trace organic atmosphere contaminants from the Space Shuttle cabin and to condition the cabin atmosphere prior to exposure to plant specimens. The AES and AFC are described and illustrated. The AFC design requirements are discussed and results are presented from tests on the performance of the AFC. Also, consideration is given to the potential applications of the AFC and future design concepts for atmosphere control.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: An atmosphere exchange system (AES) has been designed to provide a conditioned atmosphere supply to plant specimens in flight without incurring the large weight and volume associated with bottled gases . The paper examines the atmosphere filter cartridge (AFC) designed to remove trace organic atmosphere contaminants from the Space Shuttle cabin .

title: Measurement of the electron beam mode in earth's foreshock
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043505, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Onsager, T. G.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Washington Univ.', 'location': 'Seattle, WA, United States'}}, 'id': '1635f20e88c544ddbaea8ae9f0d36036'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043505, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Holzworth, R. H.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Washington, University', 'location': 'Seattle, United States'}}, 'id': 'e963ee5035ce46859db1737dcada5cc5'}]
abstract: High frequency electric field measurements from the AMPTE IRM plasma wave receiver are used to identify three simultaneously excited electrostatic wave modes in the earth's foreshock region: the electron beam mode, the Langmuir mode, and the ion acoustic mode. A technique is developed which allows the rest frame frequecy and wave number of the electron beam waves to be determined. It is shown that the experimentally determined rest frame frequency and wave number agree well with the most unstable frequency and wave number predicted by linear homogeneous Vlasov theory for a plasma with Maxwellian background electrons and a Lorentzian electron beam. From a comparison of the experimentally determined and theoretical values, approximate limits are put on the electron foreshock beam temperatures. A possible generation mechanism for ion acoustic waves involving mode coupling between the electron beam and Langmuir modes is also discussed.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: High frequency electric field measurements from the AMPTE IRM plasma wave receiver are used to identify three simultaneously excited electrostatic wave modes in the earth's foreshock region: the electron beam mode, the Langmuir mode, and the ion acoustic mode . A technique is developed which allows the rest frame frequecy and wave number of electron beam waves to be determined .

title: The possible effect of solar soft X rays on thermospheric nitric oxide
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043521, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Siskind, D. E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Michigan, University', 'location': 'Ann Arbor, United States'}}, 'id': '69ca353731494cf09d4db66b20fa3417'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043521, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Barth, C. D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'U.S. Naval Postgraduate School', 'location': 'Monterey, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '5677c9cc7ee84199b3bf8d0de50c6e4a'}]
abstract: A rocket observation of nitric oxide in the lower thermosphere during a time of high solar activity is compared to the results of calculations from a one-dimensional photochemical model. A solar soft X-ray flux of 0.75 erg/sq cm/s is needed to explain the observed NO densities. This result supports the theory that the variation in the low-latitude thermospheric NO is caused by variation in solar soft X-rays.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

abstract: The first observations of near-specularly reflected He(2+) upstream from high Mach number quasi-parallel shocks are presented. The He(2+) observations are compared with simultaneous suprathermal proton observations to determine the density ratio of specularly reflected He(2+) to protons. The presence of specularly reflected He(2+) at high Mach number quasi-parallel shocks suggests that it may be a seed population for diffuse He(2+) seen in the same region.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

Mach number . number quasi, parallel shocks suggests that it may be a seed population for diffuse He.(2+) seen in the region .

title: Do interplanetary Alfven waves cause auroral activity?
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043523, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Roberts, D. Aaron'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': 'a694892c6e07405895f4de2f5237ae94'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043523, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Goldstein, Melvyn L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': 'c65b7db3aed44d438101221cbac8c660'}]
abstract: A recent theory holds that high-intensity, long-duration, continuous auroral activity (HILDCAA) is caused by interplanetary Alfven waves propagating outward from the sun. A survey of Alfvenic intervals in over a year of ISEE 3 data shows that while Alfvenic intervals often accompany HILDCAAs, the reverse is often not true. There are many Alfvenic intervals during which auroral activity (measured by high values of the AE index) is very low, as well as times of high auroral activity that are not highly Alfvenic. This analysis supports the common conclusion that large AE values are associated with a southward interplanetary field of sufficient strength and duration. This field configuration is independent of the presence of Alfven waves (whether solar generated or not) and is expected to occur at random intervals in the large-amplitude stochastic fluctuations in the solar wind.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A recent theory holds that high-intensity, long-duration, continuous auroral activity (HILDCAA) is caused by interplanetary Alfven waves propagating outward from the sun . A survey of Alfvenic intervals in over a year of ISEE 3 data shows that while Alfvens intervals often accompany HILDCAAs, the reverse is often not true .

title: Energy absorption, lean body mass, and total body fat changes during 5 weeks of continuous bed rest
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043529, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Krebs, Jean M.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': '7bb280961b5d47baa855464f5d811de9'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043529, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Evans, Harlan'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'be66469a24dd4618a640637036aac61d'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043529, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Kuo, Mike C.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Johnson Space Center; Krug International Corp.', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'e507637e0ca14c92a6f01a77505af35f'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19900043529, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Schneider, Victor S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Texas, University', 'location': 'Houston, United States'}}, 'id': '693863b20eab4da9b0c6a5971233f600'}, {'sequence': 4, 'submissionId': 19900043529, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Leblanc, Adrian D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Baylor College of Medicine', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'f7d23ee0b0d14d54b2a527155102f536'}]
abstract: The nature of the body composition changes due to inactivity was examined together with the question of whether these changes are secondary to changes in energy absorption. Volunteers were 15 healthy males who lived on a metabolic research ward under close staff supervision for 11 weeks. Subjects were ambulatory during the first six weeks and remained in continuous bed rest for the last five weeks of the study. Six male volunteers (age 24-61 years) were selected for body composition measurements. Nine different male volunteers (age 21-50 years) were selected for energy absorption measurements. The volunteers were fed weighed conventional foods on a constant 7-d rotation menu. The average daily caloric content was 2,592 kcal. Comparing the five weeks of continuous bed rest with the previous six weeks of ambulation, it was observed that there was no change in energy absorption or total body weight during bed rest, but a significant decrease in lean body mass and a significant increase in total body fat (p less than 0.05).
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Volunteers were 15 healthy males who lived on a metabolic research ward under close staff supervision for 11 weeks . Subjects were ambulatory during the first six weeks and remained in continuous bed rest for the last five weeks of the study . The nature of the body composition changes due to inactivity was examined together with the question of whether these changes are secondary to changes in energy absorption .

title: Test of the antiorthostatic suspension model on mice - Effects on the inflammatory cell response
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043530, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Rosenkrans, Charles F., Jr.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Kansas State Univ.', 'location': 'Manhattan, KS, United States'}}, 'id': 'acf457e8843c4f7d9c50b8c8089456d1'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043530, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Chapes, Stephen K.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Kansas State Univ.', 'location': 'Manhattan, KS, United States'}}, 'id': '4f2f9a553c0a4eada57b0f02403acf65'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043530, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Fleming, Sherry D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Kansas State University', 'location': 'Manhattan, United States'}}, 'id': 'c4606318f4ed455189a14570e41e2447'}]
abstract: The antiorthostatic suspension model was tested for use as a 1G model to study the effects of factors that will be encountered during space travel on inflammation. No differences were found in inflammatory cells induced in antiorthostatically suspended mice. However, the superoxide response (used for oxidative killing of bacteria such as S. aureus) was impaired in antiorthostatically oriented mice compared to control mice. Elevated corticosterone levels were found in antiorthostatically suspended mice, indicating that stress may be a factor in the model. If the stress factor of the model correlates with the physiological stress of space flight, antiorthostatic suspension may be an acceptable model for studying inflammatory responses in mice.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The antiorthostatic suspension model was tested for use as a 1G model to study the effects of factors that will be encountered during space travel on inflammation . No differences were found in inflammatory cells induced in mice . However, the superoxide response (used for oxidative killing of bacteria such as S. aureus) was impaired in mice compared to control mice . Elevated corticosterone levels found in mice indicated stress may be a factor in the model .

title: Adaptive box filters for removal of random noise from digital images
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043550, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Eliason, Eric M.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Geological Survey', 'location': 'Flagstaff, AZ, United States'}}, 'id': '636e3a4b134844039640313aaf24d385'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043550, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mcewen, Alfred S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'USGS', 'location': 'Flagstaff, AZ, United States'}}, 'id': '0e630f0631204d80a14440b8c19fb87e'}]
abstract: Adaptive box-filtering algorithms to remove random bit errors and to smooth noisy data have been developed. For both procedures, the standard deviation of those pixels within a local box surrounding each pixel is used. A series of two or three filters with decreasing box sizes can be run to clean up extremely noisy images and to remove bit errors near sharp edges. The second filter, for noise smoothing, is similar to the 'sigma filter' of Lee (1983). The technique effectively reduces speckle in radar images without eliminating fine details.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Adaptive box-filtering algorithms to remove random bit errors and to smooth noisy data have been developed . A series of two or three filters with decreasing box sizes can be run to clean up extremely noisy images and to remove bit errors near sharp edges . The technique effectively reduces speckle in radar images without eliminating fine details .

title: Distribution of tropospheric ozone determined from satellite data
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043558, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Fishman, Jack'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '5d417db0ea3546a4ae4e9440de266701'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043558, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Watson, Catherine E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Lockheed Engineering and Sciences Co.', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '2f2e68023f83446bb98da06764b3416f'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043558, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Larsen, Jack C.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'STX Corp.', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '54e532f9d8194999ace435db5579a0ef'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19900043558, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Logan, Jennifer A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Harvard University', 'location': 'Cambridge, MA, United States'}}, 'id': '7f392cefdb7c4dffbb42928f88921901'}]
abstract: An analysis of more than 22,000 ozone profiles from Stratospheric Aerosol and Gas Experiment I (SAGE I) (1979-1981) and SAGE II (1984-1987) between 50 deg N and 50 deg S is used in conjunction with 9 years (1979-1987) of daily global depictions of total ozone from the TOMS instrument aboard Nimbus 7 to investigate the spatial distribution and seasonal cycle of the integrated amount of ozone in the troposphere. In the tropics, highest concentrations are found in the eastern Atlantic Ocean downwind (west) of Africa and maximize during the time when biomass burning is most prevalent, between July and October. A different seasonal cycle in the tropics is also observed over Indonesia, where a relative maximum is present in the March-April time frame, likewise consistent with when biomass burning is most prevalent. At mid-latitudes, highest concentrations are found downwind of Asia and maximize in the summer. Relatively higher amounts of tropospheric ozone are similarly observed downwind of North America and Europe. At mid-latitudes, the ratio between the amount of tropospheric ozone in the Northern Hemisphere and the amount in the Southern Hemisphere is 1.4, in good agreement with in situ measurements.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: An analysis of more than 22,000 ozone profiles from Stratospheric Aerosol and Gas Experiment I (SAGE I) (1979-1981) and SAGE II (1984-1987) between 50 deg N and 50 deg S is used in conjunction with 9 years of daily global depictions of total ozone from the TOMS instrument aboard Nimbus 7 . At mid-latitudes, highest concentrations are found downwind of Asia and maximize in the summer .

title: Estimates of the maximum time required to originate life
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043560, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Oberbeck, Verne R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'dfaa8899ca474c4caa0fd94339099887'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043560, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Fogleman, Guy'}, 'organization': {'name': 'SETI Institute', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '5358ea3001f14381ab5a5310d885faf4'}]
publications: [{'volume': '19', 'submissionId': 19900043560, 'issue': '6, 19', 'issn': '0169-6149', 'id': '3a07d449ecc84ea387701a840edf4558', 'publicationName': 'Origins of Life and Evolution of the Biosphere', 'publicationDate': '1989-01-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: Fossils of the oldest microorganisms exist in 3.5 billion year old rocks and there is indirect evidence that life may have existed 3.8 billion years ago (3.8 Ga). Impacts able to destroy life or interrupt prebiotic chemistry may have occurred after 3.5 Ga. If large impactors vaporized the oceans, sterilized the planets, and interfered with the origination of life, life must have originated in the time interval between these impacts which increased with geologic time. Therefore, the maximum time required for the origination of life is the time that occurred between sterilizing impacts just before 3.8 Ga or 3.5 Ga, depending upon when life first appeared on earth. If life first originated 3.5 Ga, and impacts with kinetic energies between 2 x 10 the the 34th and 2 x 10 to the 35th were able to vaporize the oceans, using the most probable impact flux, it is found that the maximum time required to originate life would have been 67 to 133 million years (My). If life originated 3.8 Ga, the maximum time to originate life was 2.5 to 11 My. Using a more conservative estimate for the flux of impacting objects before 3.8 Ga, a maximum time of 25 My was found for the same range of impactor kinetic energies. The impact model suggests that it is possible that life may have originated more than once.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Fossils of the oldest microorganisms exist in 3.5 billion year old rocks and there is indirect evidence that life may have existed 3.8 billion years ago . If large impactors vaporized the oceans, sterilized the planets, and interfered with the origination of life, life must have originated in the time interval between these impacts .

title: Processing effects on the mechanical properties of tungsten heavy alloys
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043567, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Kishi, Toshihito'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst.', 'location': 'Troy, NY, United States'}}, 'id': '8fc8508fb71e4cef971a1a1c8d77b5da'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043567, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'German, R. M.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Rensselaer Polytechnic', 'location': 'Institute, Troy, NY, United States'}}, 'id': 'd319420e89e843f9ac37b2558cb6468c'}]
publications: [{'volume': '9', 'submissionId': 19900043567, 'issn': '0263-4368', 'id': 'bd2899012e9a43f58730df18d72b299e', 'publicationName': 'International Journal of Refractory Metals and Hard Materials', 'publicationDate': '1990-03-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: Tungsten heavy alloys exhibit significant mechanical property sensitivities to the fabrication variables. These sensitivities are illustrated in this examination of vacuum sintering and the effects of composition, sintering temperature, and sintering time on the mechanical properties of tungsten heavy alloys. Measurements were conducted to assess the density, strength, hardness, and elongation dependencies. A detrimental aspect of vacuum sintering is matrix phase evaporation, although vacuum sintering does eliminate the need for postsintering heat treatments.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Tungsten heavy alloys exhibit significant mechanical property sensitivities to the fabrication variables . Measurements were conducted to assess the density, strength, hardness, and elongation dependencies . A detrimental aspect of vacuum sintering is matrix phase evaporation, although vacuuming does eliminate the need for postsintering heat treatments .

title: Mapping transformations for broadband atmospheric radiation calculations
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043568, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'West, Robert'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Jet Propulsion Lab., California Inst. of Tech.', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '805948315d2f481b9ef3f5bbb1444b8d'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043568, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Crisp, David'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Jet Propulsion Lab., California Inst. of Tech.', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '25b27e2267ca458d922b3d9f06441aa0'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043568, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Chen, Luke'}, 'organization': {'name': 'JPL', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '62a9502d5ee3466ea48236f77dae5730'}]
publications: [{'volume': '43', 'submissionId': 19900043568, 'issn': '0022-4073', 'id': 'e182aede3a90450992e3b4e6ed0ce6a0', 'publicationName': 'Journal of Quantitative Spectroscopy and Radiative Transfer', 'publicationDate': '1990-03-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: Two methods of mapping the line-by-line absorption coefficient (k) spectrum onto a new variable to produce a set of k coefficients which can be used for accurate and efficient broadband radiative transfer calculations in vertically inhomogeneous, nongray scattering atmospheres are described. These methods are intended for applications for which the less accurate correlated-k method is inadequate. These methods are tested for model atmospheres containing CO2 and H2O, with pressure in the range 0.05-0.9 bar. The results obtained differed by no more than 1 or 2 percent from the line-by-line results if the number of k coefficients was about 100 times less than the number required for the line-by-line calculation. These algorithms can be used for gas mixtures and for a variety of pressure-temperature profiles.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Two methods of mapping the line-by-line absorption coefficient (k) spectrum onto a new variable to produce a set of k coefficients which can be used for accurate and efficient broadband radiative transfer calculations in vertically inhomogeneous, nongray scattering atmospheres . These methods are intended for applications for which the less accurate correlated-k method is inadequate .

title: Phase calibration of imaging radar polarimeter Stokes matrices
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043598, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Zebker, Howard A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Jet Propulsion Lab., California Inst. of Tech.', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '3f2bb7afb89d473e99555573c4acc31a'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043598, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Lou, Yunling'}, 'organization': {'name': 'JPL', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'd6ae5939fe10423185b91384e25dc299'}]
publications: [{'volume': '28', 'submissionId': 19900043598, 'issn': '0196-2892', 'id': '0216b88e5c964f80852cbc8c2b309c27', 'publicationName': 'IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing', 'publicationDate': '1990-03-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: It is shown that the Stokes matrices measured by an imaging radar polarimeter provide enough information for the accurate phase calibration of the observed polarimetric characteristics of a surface. This is important because it allows the data to be reduced in volume in an operational synthetic aperture radar correlator with no prior knowledge of the conditions at the surface, and the end user can later select the particular region where he or she is comfortable with making an assumption regarding the relative phases of the hh and vv signals. No ground calibration equipment is necessary, as all important parameters are derived from the data themselves.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: It is shown that the Stokes matrices measured by an imaging radar polarimeter provide enough information for the accurate phase calibration of the observed polarimetric characteristics of a surface . This is important because it allows the data to be reduced in volume in an operational synthetic aperture radar correlator with no prior knowledge of the conditions at the surface .

title: Estimation of subpixel vegetation cover using red-infrared scattergrams
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043599, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Jasinski, Michael F.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': '5c8f745e2d52434b86d78fd46e347870'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043599, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Eagleson, Peter S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'MIT', 'location': 'Cambridge, MA, United States'}}, 'id': '3d8a01b6fa0e42aca5647b65e5db4ad5'}]
publications: [{'volume': '28', 'submissionId': 19900043599, 'issn': '0196-2892', 'id': '6d7137ae7688452ab2c23932b9984142', 'publicationName': 'IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing', 'publicationDate': '1990-03-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: The bulk properties of discontinuous vegetation canopies are estimated at subpixel scales by applying the method of moments to a linear stochastic geometric model of canopy-soil reflectance and one set of multispectral observations without ground truth. The procedure involves the formulation of conditional moments for subsets of pixels that possess similar properties and can be identified through their common orientation in red-infrared scattergrams. The analysis is facilitated by assuming geometric similarity among the canopy elements and by formulating a sampling scale ratio in terms of the bulk geometric scales of the canopy and the pixel. Three versions of the method are demonstrated using two simulated scenes and an actual forested watershed for which aerial radiometric data and corresponding ground truth were obtained.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

The procedure involves the formulation of conditional moments for subsets of pixels that possess similar properties and can be identified through their common orientation in red-infrared scattergrams .

title: The unpolarized component in polarimetric radar observations of forested areas
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043600, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Durden, Stephen L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Jet Propulsion Lab., California Inst. of Tech.', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '2eecec3f31af41a2829da112fc97ce5f'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043600, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Van Zyl, Jakob J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Jet Propulsion Lab., California Inst. of Tech.', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '4a2a44fba9ba4347b6867020570fd876'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043600, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Zebker, Howard A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'JPL', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'f75ac4d6c95d4186a4774f97dbf00a8f'}]
publications: [{'volume': '28', 'submissionId': 19900043600, 'issn': '0196-2892', 'id': '3c3c2da98e0d4560a7a0716d1589bb76', 'publicationName': 'IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing', 'publicationDate': '1990-03-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: A polarimetric radar measures the complete scattering matrix of a target. For the forest and other natural targets, the average return is, in general, partially polarized. Conditions on the second-order statistics of the scattering matrix under which the return is fully polarized are derived, and it is shown that these conditions are connected with the eigenvalues of the covariance matrix. The result of this analysis is a set of three quantities which indicate the ability of a scatterer to generate an unpolarized component. These quantities for forested areas are shown.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A polarimetric radar measures the complete scattering matrix of a target . For the forest and other natural targets, the average return is, in general, partially polarized . Conditions on the second-order statistics of the scattering matrix under which the return is fully polarized are derived .

title: A numerical study of the separation wavenumber in the two-scale scattering approximation
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043601, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Durden, Stephen L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'JPL', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'e41173ea5a0d467ebe84c376872b8c99'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043601, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Vesecky, John F.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Stanford University', 'location': 'CA, United States'}}, 'id': '4005399ddf6443349c64910dcc52869f'}]
publications: [{'volume': '28', 'submissionId': 19900043601, 'issn': '0196-2892', 'id': 'c1c045ceca574366bb4a047b7b66ae5b', 'publicationName': 'IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing', 'publicationDate': '1990-03-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: The choice of the separation wavenumber Kd for the two-scale scattering approximation is examined by the comparison of two-scale calculations with exact numerical solutions using the moment method. It was found that the optimal choice of Kd is near k/2 when attempting to optimize for all incidence angles. When optimizing for specific incidence angles, Kd varied from k/5 at low incidence angles to just below k at higher incidence angles. These numerical results are in rough agreement with previous theoretical derivations of the separation wavenumber.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The optimal choice of Kd is near k/2 when attempting to optimize for all incidence angles . Kd varied from k/5 at low incidence angles to just below k at higher incidence angles. These numerical results are in rough agreement with previous theoretical derivations of the separation wavenumber .

title: An American knowledge base in England - Alternate implementations of an expert system flight status monitor
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043664, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Butler, G. F.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Royal Aerospace Establishment', 'location': 'Farnborough, United Kingdom'}}, 'id': '8871d8df57ce4968b2321e9481bb4040'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043664, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Graves, A. D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'PRC System Services', 'location': 'Edwards, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '811ffc91c9904b74ba73658fc58227e7'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19900043664, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Duke, E. L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Flight Research Center', 'location': 'Edwards, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '4ab6bd05f70140d3ab99b347e9489831'}]
abstract: A joint activity between the Dryden Flight Research Facility of the NASA Ames Research Center (Ames-Dryden) and the Royal Aerospace Establishment (RAE) on knowledge-based systems has been agreed. Under the agreement, a flight status monitor knowledge base developed at Ames-Dryden has been implemented using the real-time AI (artificial intelligence) toolkit MUSE, which was developed in the UK. Here, the background to the cooperation is described and the details of the flight status monitor and a prototype MUSE implementation are presented. It is noted that the capabilities of the expert-system flight status monitor to monitor data downlinked from the flight test aircraft and to generate information on the state and health of the system for the test engineers provides increased safety during flight testing of new systems. Furthermore, the expert-system flight status monitor provides the systems engineers with ready access to the large amount of information required to describe a complex aircraft system.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A joint activity between the Dryden Flight Research Facility of the NASA Ames Research Center and the Royal Aerospace Establishment (RAE) on knowledge-based systems has been agreed . Under the agreement, a flight status monitor knowledge base developed at Ames-Dryden has been implemented using the real-time AI (artificial intelligence) toolkit MUSE .

title: Investigation of biogeophysical feedback on the African climate using a two-dimensional model
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043766, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Xue, Yongkang'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Utah Univ.', 'location': 'Salt Lake City, UT, United States'}}, 'id': '26bbfe79b2984ce1961d97455bbfed75'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043766, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Liou, Kuo-Nan'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Utah, University', 'location': 'Salt Lake City, United States'}}, 'id': '64b9d772d06a4560894022818a9f25cd'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043766, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Kasahara, Akira'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NCAR', 'location': 'Boulder, CO, United States'}}, 'id': '39065d3d6d584ddfb115e5f4ec99827e'}]
abstract: A numerical scheme is specifically designed to develop a time-dependent climate model to ensure the conservation of mass, momentum, energy, and water vapor, in order to study the biogeophysical feedback for the climate of Africa. A vegetation layer is incorporated in the present two-dimensional climate model. Using the coupled climate-vegetation model, two tests were performed involving the removal and expansion of the Sahara Desert. Results show that variations in the surface conditions produce a significant feedback to the climate system. It is noted that the simulation responses to the temperature and zonal wind in the case of an expanded desert agree with the climatological data for African dry years. Perturbed simulations have also been performed by changing the albedo only, without allowing the variation in the vegetation layer. It is shown that the variation in latent heat release is significant and is related to changes in the vegetation cover. As a result, precipitation and cloud cover are reduced.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A vegetation layer is incorporated in the present two-dimensional climate model . Using the coupled climate-vegetation model, two tests were performed involving the removal and expansion of the Sahara Desert . Results show that variations in the surface conditions produce a significant feedback to the climate system .

title: Carbon-rich aggregates in type 3 ordinary chondrites - Characterization, origins, and thermal history
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043793, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Brearley, Adrian J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'New Mexico, University', 'location': 'Albuquerque, United States'}}, 'id': '432d36d941c741bbb53cef1b5c1f512a'}]
abstract: Carbon-rich aggregates from three type 3.4-3.6 ordinary chondrites and two chondritic clasts have been characterized in detail, using TEM techniques. The aggregates in all the meteorites studied range in size from 5-1000 microns and consist of a fine scale intergrowth of poorly graphitized carbon, amorphous carbon, Fe,Ni metal, and minor chromite. Contrary to previous reports, well-crystallized graphite and magnetite are absent. The association of Fe,Ni metal and carbonaceous material suggests that the original carbonaceous material may have formed by Fischer-Tropsch (FT) type reactions at low temperatures (less than 400 K), possibly in the solar nebula. This carbonaceous material probably consisted of a complex mixture of hydrocarbons, kerogen-like material, and other complex organic molecules. The aggregates were subsequently accreted onto the ordinary chondrite parent bodies and underwent planetary thermal processing which resulted in the catalytic graphitization of hydrocarbons, in the presence of Fe,Ni metal, to produce poorly graphitized carbon. None of the meteorites studied experienced temperatures sufficiently high to produce crystalline, ordered graphite. Using the empirical geothermometer of Rietmeijer and Mackinnon (1985), the measured d(002) spacings of poorly graphitized carbon show that graphitization occurred at temperatures between 300 and 450 C. This range of temperatures is significantly lower than the generally quoted metamorphic temperatures for type 3.4-3.6 ordinary chondrites (about 450-500 C).
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Carbon-rich aggregates from three type 3.4-3.6 ordinary chondrites and two chondritic clasts have been characterized in detail . The original carbonaceous material may have formed by Fischer-Tropsch (FT) type reactions at low temperatures (less than 400 K), possibly in the solar nebula .

abstract: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory InterDisciplinary Model for precision composite structures is described along with the HAVOC composite computer code used to study laminate mirror facesheets. The composite mirror panel thermal behavior is described in addition to structural and optical characteristics. Environmental mirror performance testing and performance test/prediction correlation are covered.

title: X-ray observations of two short but intense solar flares
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043880, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Nitta, Nariaki'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt; Maryland, University, College Park, United States'}}, 'id': 'f4934ad5cde84b2983a9ecf09447121f'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043880, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Dennis, Brian R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': '09b504461a1c413ba1e19291b3c9a1ed'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043880, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Kiplinger, Alan L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Colorado, University;', 'location': 'NOAA, Space Environment Laboratory, Boulder, United States'}}, 'id': 'f040b932a61b46e9b9bb51817968a97d'}]
abstract: This paper presents continuum X-ray spectra of impulsive emission in two short but intense solar flares which have relatively weak soft X-ray emissions, combining data obtained with soft X-ray and hard X-ray spectrometers on board two satellites, the SMM and Hinotori. In both flares, photon spectra of the impulsive component are found to flatten toward low energies, suggesting that a low-energy cutoff of the electron spectrum could be greater than about 50 keV and that the total energy contained in the electrons is significantly less than that usually quoted for a cutoff energy of about 20 keV. Different shapes of the X-ray spectrum at energies below 50 keV in other flares can be attributed to the variety in the relative strength of gradual and impulsive emissions. In one of the two flares, observations with the imager on Hinotori suggest that hard X-ray emission is likely to be associated with loop footpoints. It is argued that contamination by the gradual soft X-ray emission and/or the asymmetry of loops could explain the detection of single sources in the majority of flares that have been imaged in hard X-rays.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: This paper presents continuum X-ray spectra of impulsive emission in two short but intense solar flares which have relatively weak soft X-rays . In both flares, photons of the impulsive component are found to flatten toward low energies, suggesting that a low-energy cutoff of the electron spectrum could be greater than about 50 keV .

title: Evidence for an inner scale to the density turbulence in the interstellar medium
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043889, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Spangler, Steven R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Iowa, University', 'location': 'Iowa City, United States'}}, 'id': 'f921f469cfd746c4b429c6e7e57c6460'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043889, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Gwinn, Carl R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'California, University', 'location': 'Santa Barbara, United States'}}, 'id': 'f78ae106e996474b877085a3fc5ac91a'}]
abstract: The form of the density power spectrum is studied. The relationship between the visibility and the properties of density turbulence is discussed. Observational determinations of the power-law index of the interstellar density power spectrum are presented. An inner scale is derived, and the effect of an inner scale in the interstellar plasma turbulence is examined. It is concluded that the host plasma for the density irregularities must be similar to the warm ionized medium in the Mckee-Ostriker model (1979) of the interstellar medium or the low-density envelopes of H II regions.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The form of the density power spectrum is studied . The relationship between the visibility and the properties of density turbulence is discussed . The host plasma for the density irregularities must be similar to the warm ionized medium in the Mckee-Ostriker model of the interstellar medium or the low-density envelopes of H II regions .

title: Permanent uplift in magmatic systems with application to the Tharsis region of Mars
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043895, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Phillips, Roger J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Southern Methodist University', 'location': 'Dallas, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'e6f3d2591848497396b3b59c49178387'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043895, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Sleep, Norman H.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Stanford University', 'location': 'CA, United States'}}, 'id': '6533e06a3f074458bdcfed28a8cc5481'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900043895, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Banerdt, W. Bruce'}, 'organization': {'name': 'JPL', 'location': 'Pasadena, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '4e95bffe820c44b9aa41de0844d7f608'}]
abstract: A model is derived for predicting both crustal displacement (leading to permanent uplift) and topographic elevation in regional large-scale magmatic systems associated with partial melting of mantle rocks. The model is then applied to the Tharsis region of Mars to test the uplift versus construction. It was found that a lower bound estimate of the fraction of intrusives necessary for any uplift at all is about 85 percent of the total magmatic products at Tharsis. Thus, it is proposed that most of the magmas associated with Tharsis evolution ended up as intrusive bodies in the crust and upper mantle.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A model is derived for predicting both crustal displacement (leading to permanent uplift) and topographic elevation in regional large-scale magmatic systems . The model is then applied to the Tharsis region of Mars to test the uplift versus construction . It was found that a lower bound estimate of the fraction of intrusives necessary for any uplift at all is about 85 percent of the total magmatic products .

title: Turbulent polar heliospheric fields
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043974, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Roberts, D. A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': 'bfaf977c350e4214a340fea8d5e7e34a'}]
abstract: Recent observational studies of interplanetary field fluctuations and MHD simulation results are used to suggest that the turbulent evolution of the fields over the solar poles leads to a state intermediate between the large fields of the static limit and the small fields given by 'saturation' (deltaB/B = about 1). In particular, assuming the strength of the coronal hole sources of fluctuations are similar in all solar regions, the polar fluctuations in the outer heliosphere are likely to be nearly isotropic, with amplitudes somewhat smaller than those predicted by the WKB extrapolation from 1 AU in the ecliptic plane.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Recent observational studies of interplanetary field fluctuations suggest turbulent evolution of the fields over the solar poles leads to a state intermediate between the large fields of the static limit and the small fields given by 'saturation' (deltaB/B = about 1) In particular, assuming the strength of the coronal hole sources of fluctuations are similar in all solar regions, polar fluctuations in the outer heliosphere are likely to be nearly isotropic .

title: Particle acceleration during substorm growth and onset
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900043979, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Williams, D. J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Johns Hopkins Univ.', 'location': 'Laurel, MD, United States'}}, 'id': '051756900f4d457d89884b129f1ff752'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900043979, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mitchell, D. T.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'California, University', 'location': 'Los Angeles, United States'}}, 'id': 'fa9f7b0953a94412ab7baa54c1d29e80'}]
abstract: ISEE-1 observations of ion and electron energization made at 11 RE during a substorm event on April 2, 1978 are presented. An analysis of the dominant cross-tail current systems in this event (Mitchell et al., 1990) has made it possible to uniquely associate particle energization processes with the development and/or disruption of the cross-tail currents. It is found that significant ion acceleration occurs as the ions participate in serpentine cross-tail motion (Speiser, 1965), establishing the dominant plasma sheet current system just prior to onset. As this current disrupts, the magnetic field configuration dipolarizes and further ion energization and the bulk of the electron energization occurs. During dipolarization energization is due primarily to the inductive electric field, including betatron and Fermi acceleration processes.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

An analysis of the dominant cross-tail current systems in this event has made it possible to uniquely associate particle energization processes with the development and/or disruption of the cross tail currents .

abstract: Instantaneous signals from coherent random sound field are summed and time delayed to avoid introducing vectorial addition errors. Resultant statistically independent signals are applied to spectrometer. Displayed sound pressure level is proportional to square root of sum of squares of sound pressure levels taken over frequency range of interest.

title: Effect of size on cracking of materials
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19710000157, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Glucklick, J.'}, 'organization': {}}, 'id': '90fec27b3ee14b36a117cd6cd18cd4b2'}]
abstract: Brittle behavior of large mild steel elements, glass plasticity, and fatigue specimen size sensitivity are manifestations of strain-energy size effect. Specimens physical size effect on material cracking initiation occurs according to flaw distribution statistics. Fracture size effect depends on stability or instability of crack propagation.

abstract: Judicious selection and maintenance of tape and tape transports minimizes dropouts.

abstract: Heart diameter is derived from measured transit time of 2.25 MHz ultrasonic pulse between two piezoelectric crystals attached to diametrically opposite heart surfaces. Miniature instrument implanted in chest telemeters information to external receiver-converter. System permits continual dimensional data recording taken from awake animals during long-term experiments.

title: Parallel-gap welding for joints between copper conductors and Kovar
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19710000167, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mc Daniel, G. E.'}, 'organization': {}}, 'id': '1840424402c34fdd929ebc1b4e675680'}]
abstract: Welding technique produces more reliable joints than soldering. Investigation used different sizes of copper conductors and component lead ribbons, corrosion protection platings, and melting points of metals being joined. Optimum combination is gold-plated component lead ribbons and solder-plated copper conductors.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

Optimum combination is gold-plated component lead ribbon and solder-plate copper conductor .

title: New bound on neutrino dipole moments from globular-cluster stars
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049627, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Raffelt, Georg G.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik', 'location': 'Munich, Federal Republic of Germany, United States'}}, 'id': '6041e30e13934a85b85fc87f45f4b6dc'}]
abstract: Neutrino dipole moments mu(nu) would increase the core mass of red giants at the helium flash by delta(Mc) = 0.015 solar mass x mu(nu)/10 to the -12th muB (where muB is the Bohr magneton) because of enhanced neutrino losses. Existing measurements of the bolometric magnitudes of the brightest red giants in 26 globular clusters, number counts of horizontal-branch stars and red giants in 15 globular clusters, and statistical parallax determinations of field RR Lyr luminosities yield delta(Mc) = 0.009 + or - 0.012 solar mass, so that conservatively mu(nu) is less than 3 x 10 to the -12th muB.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Neutrino dipole moments mu(nu) would increase the core mass of red giants at the helium flash by delta(Mc) = 0.015 solar mass xmu(nu)/10 to the -12th muB (where muB is the Bohr magneton) because of enhanced neutrino losses .

title: A bit-serial VLSI array processing chip for image processing
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049668, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Heaton, Robert'}, 'organization': {'name': 'North Carolina, Microelectronics Center', 'location': 'Research Triangle Park, United States'}}, 'id': 'a0820641a2b84168b21b6abb3dd1bab2'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900049668, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Blevins, Donald'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Precision Products Corp.', 'location': 'Lexington, KY, United States'}}, 'id': '305338e58fb6431385226aabe75509f9'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19900049668, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Davis, Edward'}, 'organization': {'name': 'North Carolina State University', 'location': 'Raleigh, United States'}}, 'id': '997bf5dd78c3447ab4072012b2d27d2a'}]
abstract: An array processing chip integrating 128 bit-serial processing elements (PEs) on a single die is discussed. Each PE has a 16-function logic unit, a single-bit adder, a 32-b variable-length shift register, and 1 kb of local RAM. Logic in each PE provides the capability to mask PEs individually. A modified grid interconnection scheme allows each PE to communicate with each of its eight nearest neighbors. A 32-b bus is used to transfer data to and from the array in a single cycle. Instruction execution is pipelined, enabling all instructions to be executed in a single cycle. The 1-micron CMOS design contains over 1.1 x 10 to the 6th transistors on an 11.0 x 11.7-mm die.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: An array processing chip integrating 128 bit-serial processing elements (PEs) on a single die is discussed . Each PE has a 16-function logic unit, a single-bit adder, a 32-b variable-length shift register, and 1kb of local RAM . Instruction execution is pipelined, enabling all instructions to be executed in a single cycle .

title: Intensity noise in diode-pumped single-frequency Nd:YAG lasers and its control by electronic feedback
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049676, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Kane, Thomas J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Lightwave Electronics Corp.', 'location': 'Mountain View, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '04a9f2cf04b54c32807e4188c528129e'}]
abstract: The power spectrum of the relative intensity noise (RIN) of single-frequency diode-pumped Nd:YAG lasers is observed to be shot-noise limited at frequencies above 20 MHz for a photocurrent of up to 4.4 mA. Relaxation oscillations result in noise 60-70 dB above shot noise at a few hundred kHz. These relaxation oscillations have been suppressed using electronic feedback.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The power spectrum of the relative intensity noise (RIN) of single-frequency diode-pumped Nd:YAG lasers is observed to be shot-noise limited at frequencies above 20 MHz for a photocurrent of up to 4.4 mA . Relaxation oscillations result in noise 60-70 dB above shot noise at a few hundred kHz .

publications: [{'volume': '8', 'submissionId': 19900049744, 'issn': '0734-2101', 'id': '416a34e87e8f4bcb9f686b355a5eb5ce', 'publicationName': 'Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A', 'publicationDate': '1990-06-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: While dc magnetron sputter deposition of indium tin oxide leads to the formation of a buried homojunction in single crystal p-type InP, the mechanism of type conversion of the InP surface is not apparent. In view of the recent achievement of nearly 17-percent global efficiencies for cells fabricated solely by sputter deposition of In2O3, it is presently surmised that tin may not be an essential element in type conversion. A variety of electrical and optical techniques are presently used to evaluate the changes at both indium tin oxide/InP and indium oxide/InP interfaces. Such mechanisms as the passivation of acceptors by hydrogen, and sputter damage, are found to occur simultaneously.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

In view of the recent achievement of nearly 17-percent global efficiencies for cells fabricated solely by sputtering deposition of In2O3, it is surmised that tin may not be an essential element in type conversion .

abstract: UV and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic methods are presently used to study the band-bending behavior and interfacial chemistry of Al, In, Ag, and Pt overlayers on vacuum-cleaved p-CdTe and p-ZnTe (110). All four metals are found to yield Schottky barriers on CdTe and ZnTe. The metal-induced gap states model prediction of a difference in barrier heights for two semiconductors which is dependent on their band lineup is borne out by the results for Ag, Pt, and Al, but not for In. Reaction and intermixing for Al, Ag, and Pt overlayers on CdTe and ZnTe indicate that these interfaces are not ideal.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: UV and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic methods are presently used to study the band-bending behavior and interfacial chemistry of Al, In, Ag, and Pt overlayers on vacuum-cleaved p-CdTe and p-ZnTe (110) All four metals are found to yield Schottky barriers on ZnTe and CdTe .

title: A theoretical prediction of hydrogen molecule dissociation-recombination rates including an accurate treatment of internal state nonequilibrium effects
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049781, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Schwenke, David W.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '76da9f2c77054221afdca8a087b57114'}]
abstract: The dissociation and recombination of H2 over the temperature range 1000-5000 K are calculated in a nonempirical manner. The computation procedure involves the calculation of the state-to-state energy transfer rate coefficients, the solution of the 349 coupled equations which form the master equation, and the determination of the phenomenological rate coefficients. The nonempirical results presented here are in good agreement with experimental data at 1000 and 3000 K.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The dissociation and recombination of H2 over the temperature range 1000-5000 K are calculated in a nonempirical manner . The computation procedure involves the calculation of the state-to-state energy transfer rate coefficients, the solution of the 349 coupled equations which form the master equation .

title: Wolf-Rayet nebulae - Chemical enrichment and effective temperatures of the exciting stars
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049816, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Rosa, Michael R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'European Southern Observatory', 'location': 'Garching, Federal Republic of Germany, United States'}}, 'id': '81e4ebac48f145b18320736b93d75aa2'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900049816, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mathis, John S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Washburn Observatory', 'location': 'Madison, WI, United States'}}, 'id': '21e411519faf47418c530d56d4d33679'}]
abstract: Extensive new spectrophotometric observations of five Wolf-Rayet nebulas are analyzed by means of models photoionized by plane-parallel and also WR atmosphere models. Abundance ratios O/H and Ne, S, Cl, and Ar relative to O are close to solar. N/H is enriched relative to solar and variable over the faces of the nebulas. He/H varies from one to three times solar. The O(+)/O - S(+)/S(2+) diagram is used in estimating T(eff) for the exciting stars. It indicates that S 308, NGC 3199, NGC 6888, and NGC 2359 are ionized by hot stars. RCW 58, RCW 104, MR 26, and MR 100 have such low-excitation spectra that their stellar T(eff) and nebular He/H cannot be reliably determined.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
meetings: [{'country': 'United States', 'submissionId': 19900049816, 'endDate': '1988-08-11T00:00:00.0000000+00:00', 'name': 'Boulder-Munich Workshop on Hot Luminous Stars', 'location': 'Boulder, CO', 'id': '04a509769b644d2599807f06523a69e6', 'startDate': '1988-08-06T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
summary: Five Wolf-Rayet nebulas are analyzed by means of models photoionized by plane-parallel and WR atmosphere models . Abundance ratios O/H and Ne, S, Cl, and Ar relative to O are close to solar . He/H varies from one to three times solar . RCW 58, RCW 104, MR 26 and MR 100 have such low-excitation spectra that their stellar T(eff) cannot be reliably determined .

title: Models of Wolf-Rayet stars
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049839, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Langer, Norbert'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Lick Observatory', 'location': 'Santa Cruz, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'e0efb6fd2c8c45baa23b4df714fe1050'}]
abstract: The current status of knowledge about formation, structure and evolution of Wolf-Rayet stars is reviewed, with emphasis on a discussion of corresponding stellar models. The relevance of the LBV-scenario for WR star formation is outlined. Hydrogenless WR stars are shown to closely follow simple relations for the dependence of luminosity, radius, and surface temperature as a function of their mass. The use of these relations for simplified WR evolution calculations is demonstrated. Surface abundance predictions for the different WR types are discussed, with special emphasis to the WN + WC spectral type. Details are presented concerning the WR phase of a recent 60 solar mass evolutionary calculation, which was computed with the same input physics which reproduced the progenitor evolution of SN 1987 A in a 20 solar mass case, and which may be a representative case concerning WR stars in many respects.

title: Observation of an antenna-plasma instability
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049905, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Kellogg, P. J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Minnesota Univ.', 'location': 'Minneapolis, MN, United States'}}, 'id': '50debf20318f441498a4f1a0ebf17371'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900049905, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Monson, S. abstract: This paper investigates the conditions leading to, and the causes of, the phenomenon observed during a rocket flight (to 585-km altitude) of an occasionally occurring narrow-band signal on an electric antenna whose frequency was found to vary as the rocket turned. The amplitude also varied by a factor larger than can be explained by variable coupling to the plasma; maximum oscillation amplitude occurred when the antenna was aligned with the earth's magnetic field. A tentative explanation of this phenomenon is given, suggesting that the signals on the antenna were caused by an interacton of the flowing plasma with sheath waves around the antenna.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

abstract: This paper presents Dynamic Explorer data on the plasma coupling between the plasmasphere and ionosphere. DE 1 measurements of ion composition and temperatures at 1.4-3.5 R(F) in the plasmasphere were combined with DE-2 measurements of ion composition and electron and ion temperatures in the upper F region/topside ionosphere, closely spaced in universal and local time for cases in the November 6-11, 1981 period. The observations are compared directly with the field-line interhemispheric plasma (FLIP) model calculations of altitudinal ion density and temperature profiles. It was found that, when the FLIP model permitted fractional trapping of ionospheric photoelectrons and consequent plasmaspheric heating, good agreement with the observations was obtained.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

DE 1 measurements of ion composition and temperatures at 1.4-3.5 R(F) in the plashere were combined with DE-2 measurements . The observations are compared directly with field-line interhemispheric plasma (FLIP) model calculations of altitudinal ion density and temperature profiles .

title: Magnetic field-aligned coupling effects on ionospheric plasma structure
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049921, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Heelis, R. A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Texas, University', 'location': 'Richardson, United States'}}, 'id': 'b17c2ba601ff4c519fb0b8a9a8678c6a'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900049921, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Vickrey, J. F.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'SRI International', 'location': 'Menlo Park, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '5333b4b71b6a4b528ac724e267b0ed1c'}]
abstract: This paper presents a mathematical description of the electrical coupling and dynamics of plasma structure in the E and F regions. The scale size dependence of the electric field coupling along the magnetic field is examined for a realistic background ionosphere and atmosphere. It is shown that, while normalized potentials map reciprocally between two altitudes, the potential disturbance caused by a fixed amplitude plasma density perturbation does not. The magnitude of electrostatic potential created by structured ionization is also shown to be strongly dependent on the altitude of the structure. The role of diffusion parallel to the magnetic field in the redistribution and decay of plasma structure is illustrated.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

title: A multisatellite case study of the expansion of a substorm current wedge in the near-earth magnetotail
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049922, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Lopez, R. E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Johns Hopkins Univ.', 'location': 'Laurel, MD, United States'}}, 'id': '8401d0be3dae4c05b73a4cb98608398f'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19900049922, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Lui, A. T. Y.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Johns Hopkins University', 'location': 'Laurel, MD, United States'}}, 'id': 'e9caa168db084981b8a1424fb8e024a2'}]
abstract: Results are presented on observations from four satellites (GOES 5, GOES 6, AMPTE CCE, and AMPTE IRM) and two ground stations (San Juan and Tucson) on a substorm that occurred on April 19, 1985 at about 0830 UT. The four spacecraft were arrayed in a configuration that made it possible to separate the effects arising from the longitudinal versus the radial expansion of the substorm current wedge and thus to examine its spatial evolution. The sequence of events that was observed suggests that, during this substorm, the disruption of the cross-tail current sheet, the formation of the substorm current wedge, and the expansion of the plasma sheet began in the near-earth region, and subsequently spread tailward as well as longitudinally.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Results are presented on observations from four satellites and two ground stations on a substorm that occurred on April 19, 1985 at about 0830 UT . The disruption of the cross-tail current sheet, the formation of the substorm current wedge, and the expansion of the plasma sheet began in the near-earth region, and subsequently spread tailward as well as longitudinally .

title: The distortion of the magnetotail equilibrium structure by a net cross-tail magnetic field
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19900049923, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Birn, J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Los Alamos National Laboratory', 'location': 'NM, United States'}}, 'id': '250b0d9d0f774243b3d812727ad76493'}]
abstract: Explicit solutions are presented for quiet, quasi-static magnetotail configurations in the presence of a net cross-tail magnetic field component in addition to field components associated with tail flaring. The solutions are derived using the general three-dimensional equilibrium theory of Birn (1987). It is found that the net By(N) field varies only weakly along field lines and across the tail. The presence of the net By(N) in the neutral sheet implies that a part of the cross-tail current becomes field-aligned, flowing from the southern to the northern hemisphere for By(N) larger than zero and from north to south for By(n) less than zero. The deformations of magnetic flux surfaces suggest that there may be a class of field lines extending from the earth into the magnetosheath region through the low-latitude flanks of the tail. A topological connection is found of the low-latitude region near the magnetopause with the plasma sheet boundary layer, separating closed plasma sheet and open lobe field lines.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Explicit solutions are presented for quiet, quasi-static magnetotail configurations in the presence of a net cross-tail magnetic field component . The solutions are derived using the general three-dimensional equilibrium theory of Birn (1987) It is found that the net By(N) field varies only weakly along field lines and across tail .

title: Plasma flow reversals at the dayside magnetopause and the origin of asymmetric polar cap convection
