abstract: Thermal ion characteristics in the vicinity of the Space Shuttle, derived from RF spectrometer measurements of the Plasma Diagnostic Package (PDP) flown aboard Spacelab 2, are discussed. During the Reaction Control System firings, short pulses of enhanced ion fluxes of NO(+), O2(+), and H2O(+) were detected in the near wake within and in near proximity to the open payload. During the release of the PDP as a free flying satellite, the spin modulation of the ion fluxes in the ion spectrometer indicated the presence of plasma streams of O(+) and H2O(+) which were separated in direction by as much as 77 deg. It is concluded that the presence of contaminant NO and O2(+) ions makes the near environment of the Shuttle an unsuitable place for obtaining accurate ambient ion concentration measurements.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Thermal ion characteristics in the vicinity of the Space Shuttle, derived from RF spectrometer measurements of the Plasma Diagnostic Package (PDP) flown aboard Spacelab 2 . During the Reaction Control System firings, short pulses of enhanced ion fluxes of NO(+), O2(+, and H2O(+) were detected in the near wake within and in near proximity to the open payload .

title: Recent progress in understanding QPO sources
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870053655, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Brainerd, J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Stanford University', 'location': 'CA; California, University, Livermore, United States'}}, 'id': '27e423e0503049e2b0c88605818d9771'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870053655, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Lamb, F. K.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Illinois, University', 'location': 'Urbana, United States'}}, 'id': 'e9fbf064fc604821b2657628f9b25c4e'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870053655, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Shibazaki, N.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Marshall Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Huntsville, AL, United States'}}, 'id': '83d2ee4236014adbbfbf3642404661b0'}]
abstract: New observational and theoretical results strongly suggest that QPOs in the fast, luminous sources are caused by oscillations in the luminosity of the X-ray star. They also explain why coherent pulsations at the stellar rotation frequency are so weak in these sources. Observations of weak red noise suggest that the luminosity oscillations in some sources are partially coherent.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

They also explain why coherent pulsations at the stellar rotation frequency are so weak in these sources . Observations of weak red noise suggest that the luminosities in some sources are partially coherent .

title: Turbulent solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870053658, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Deissler, R. G.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Lewis Research Center', 'location': 'Cleveland, OH, United States'}}, 'id': '2f8e1a261cb74242a9142e1a85f862ad'}]
abstract: Analytical and numerical approaches to the mechanics of turbulent flow are examined in a general introduction and illustrated with graphs. Topics discussed include the averaged and unaveraged basic equations, numerical solutions and methods, homogeneous fluctuations and turbulence with no mean flow, uniformly sheared fluctuations and turbulence, inhomogeneous fluctuations and turbulence in a developing shear layer, and steady-state homogeneous turbulence with a spatially periodic body force.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

Topics discussed include the averaged and unaveraged basic equations, numerical solutions and methods, homogeneous fluctuations and turbulence with no mean flow, and steady-state homogeneous turbulence with a spatially periodic body force .

authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870053665, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Norbury, J. W.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Old Dominion Univ.', 'location': 'Norfolk, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'bebec993f1454f269b1e001a01e7a7cb'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870053665, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Badavi, F. W.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '789f600893f64ad7a67a0f8dea50c02c'}]
abstract: The nonrelativistic quark model is applied to heavy (nonrelativistic) meson (two-body) systems to obtain sufficiently accurate predictions of the spin-averaged mass levels of the charmonium and bottomonium spectra as an example of the three-dimensional harmonic oscillator. The present calculations do not include any spin dependence, but rather, mass values are averaged for different spins. Results for a charmed quark mass value of 1500 MeV/c-squared show that the simple harmonic oscillator model provides good agreement with experimental values for 3P states, and adequate agreement for the 3S1 states.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

title: Quantitative photoabsorption and fluorescence study of H2O and D2O at 50-190 nm
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870053677, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Lee, L. C.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'San Diego State Univ.', 'location': 'San Diego, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '28e01cf06a134836ba46548fdd38dd7d'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870053677, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Suto, Masako'}, 'organization': {'name': 'San Diego State University', 'location': 'CA, United States'}}, 'id': '2fd33b7a929b4103b76666020ecd52d6'}]
abstract: The photoabsorption cross sections and the fluorescence quantum yields of H2O and D2O were measured in the 50-190 nm region using synchrotron radiation as a light source. The oscillator strengths for the Rydberg states of H2O and D2O were determined from the absorption cross sections measured. The processes for the production of fluorescence from the excited species H(asterisk) (n greater than 2), D(asterisk) (n greater than 2), OH(asterisk) (A) and OD(asterisk) (A) are discussed. The upper limit for the dissociation energy of D(D-OD) was determined, from the threshold of the OD(A-X) fluorescence, to be 5.14 + or - 0.01 eV. The upper limit for the cross section of visible fluorescence from the excited H2O(+) ions was determined to be 2 x 10 to the -19th sq cm. A comparison between the photoexcitation spectra of H2O and D2O is made.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The photoabsorption cross sections and fluorescence quantum yields of H2O and D2O were measured in the 50-190 nm region using synchrotron radiation as a light source . The processes for the production of fluorescence from the excited species H(asterisk) are discussed . The upper limit for the dissociation energy of D(D-OD) was determined to be 5.14 + or - 0.01 eV .

title: The effects of pin elasticity, clearance, and friction on the stresses in a pin-loaded orthotropic plate
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870053739, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Hyer, M. W.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Maryland, University', 'location': 'College Park, United States'}}, 'id': '1b3576bf0117400ab22a70ae6e2c58e1'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870053739, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Klang, E. C.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'North Carolina State University', 'location': 'Raleigh, United States'}}, 'id': '464764a565144c09854873e3d485066c'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870053739, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Cooper, D. E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Boeing Aerospace Co.', 'location': 'Seattle, WA, United States'}}, 'id': 'c399157dd6ec481e8ef827e55d5b0dfd'}]
abstract: The effects of pin elasticity, clearance, and friction on the stresses in a pin loaded orthotropic plate are studied. The effects are studied by posing the problem as a planar contact elasticity problem, the pin and the plate being two elastic bodies which interact through contact. Coulomb friction is assumed, the pin loads the plate in one of its principal material directions, and the plate is infinite in extent. A collocation scheme and interaction, in conjunction with a complex variable series solution, are used to obtain numerical results. The contact region between the plate and pin is unknown and must be solved for as part of the solution. The same is true of the region of friction induced no slip. Two pin stiffnesses, two clearance levels, two friction levels and two laminates, a (0/+ or - 45/90)s and a (02/+ or - 45)s, are studied. The effects of pin elasticity, clearance, and friction on the load capacity of the plate are assessed by comparing the load capacity of the plate with the capacity when the pin is rigid, perfectly fitting, and frictionless.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The effects of pin elasticity, clearance, and friction on the stresses in a pin loaded orthotropic plate are studied . The effects are studied by posing the problem as a planar contact elasticity problem . The contact region between the plate and pin is unknown and must be solved for as part of the solution .

title: An aerothermodynamic study of slender conical vehicles
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055734, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Thompson, R. A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'dabc23d3b7f243258328443b261e3ce3'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055734, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Zoby, E. V.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'de9eb9b10b374ae585b1558395d9f4f7'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870055734, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Wurster, K. E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '5c2a40695700457fac430d3af7f578d6'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19870055734, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Gnoffo, P. A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'ebd2618885ac4f038e92fc5c8378365d'}]
abstract: A numerical study was performed to assess the applicability of some current techniques which can be used for aerothermal predictions over slender spherically blunted cones. Predictions using a viscous-shock-layer method and several engineering approaches were compared with experimental results from flight and ground-based tests, with each other, and with other detailed results. Good agreement was obtained in comparisons with laminar and turbulent heating data from the Reentry F flight vehicle and with the wind-tunnel data. In particular, the viscous-shock-layer method was shown to yield excellent comparisons and should be useful in providing detailed flowfield and surface values for slender blunted cones. Additional predictions were obtained with these methods for two 5-deg half-angle cones with different nose radii to illustrate the effects of nose bluntness and angle of attack on drag and heat transfer. These results demonstrate the benefit of nose blunting with respect to heating and drag for laminar and transitional flow at zero-lift conditions and the benefit of heating reduction at angle of attack. Detailed comparison of the engineering code predictions with the viscous-shock-layer results for these additional cases generally showed good agreement except for the laminar prodictions at angle of attack on the forward cone surface. Nonequilibrium calculations at 0-deg angle of attack showed that substantial benefits of low surface catalysis existed only in the nose-dominated region.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A numerical study was performed to assess the applicability of some current techniques which can be used for aerothermal predictions over slender spherically blunted cones . Predictions using a viscous-shock-layer method and several engineering approaches were compared with experimental results from flight and ground-based tests .

title: Experimental measurement of solutal and thermal layers in unidirectional solidification
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055751, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mccay, M. H.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Tennessee Univ.', 'location': 'Tullahoma, TN, United States'}}, 'id': 'eb10a3368c71408c99270149ef646b16'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055751, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Mccay, T. D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Tennessee, University', 'location': 'Tullahoma, United States'}}, 'id': '8dfb8d80ecdd4856a18c6c2ba20cd803'}]
abstract: An experimental study to evaluate and characterize the effects and causes of convection in the directional solidification of metal alloys is described. The temporal history of the inverted density layers in front of a dendritic interface for directionally solidified ammonium chloride-(72 wt pct) water is presented based on photographic data taken using a laser schlieren system. Data are given for both 1-g and low-g solidification runs, and the stability of the layer is discussed. The reduction of buoyancy effects is shown to be significant, and the possible impact of reducing gravity level on freckling in metal alloys is considered.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: An experimental study to evaluate and characterize the effects and causes of convection in the directional solidification of metal alloys is described . The reduction of buoyancy effects is shown to be significant, and the possible impact of reducing gravity level on freckling is considered . Data are given for both 1-g and low-g solidification runs, and stability of the layer is discussed .

title: Evaluation of cryogenic system test options for the OTV on-orbit propellant depot
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055753, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Schuster, John R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'General Dynamics Corp.', 'location': 'San Diego, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'f1396859924f47c7be941aba1c700964'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055753, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Alton, T. James'}, 'organization': {'name': 'General Dynamics Corp.', 'location': 'Space Systems Div., San Diego, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '8ca3e45b5d64419c854fdbcd872ad662'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870055753, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Brown, Norman S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'General Dynamics Corp.', 'location': 'San Diego, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '5f3867cbeae842df82e760a8a1063782'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19870055753, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Hueter, Uwe'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Marshall Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Huntsville, AL, United States'}}, 'id': 'f82ba904881847b8a2ad8811b9245b13'}]
abstract: Future space missions to geosynchronous, lunar, and planetary orbits will require an orbital depot for stockpiling propellants. This depot will provide long-term storage of cryogens, requiring new technologies for fluid management in microgravity and further development of thermal management technologies for minimization of cryogen boiloff. Preliminary evaluations have been made to define a test program approach for reducing technical risk through verifying performance models and building a base of engineering data for depot design. A number of testing options were defined and evaluated, leading to selection of ground testing combined with an orbital systems test. Ground testing is inadequate because of critical microgravity concerns; extending testing aboard the Space Station was eliminated because the data would not be available soon enough to benefit the propellant depot design. The orbital test would either be a short-term test carried out in the cargo bay of the Space Shuttle Orbiter using a nonhazardous cryogen or a longer term test carried out with hydrogen aboard a free-flying experiment orbited with an expendable launch vehicle.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Future space missions to geosynchronous, lunar, and planetary orbits will require an orbital depot for stockpiling propellants . This depot will provide long-term storage of cryogens, requiring new technologies for fluid management in microgravity and further development of thermal management technologies for minimization of cryogen boiloff .

title: The rationale for an aeroassist flight experiment
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055759, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Jones, Jim J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Analytical Machines Associates, Inc.', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'c03e98032e4b47fab131f2907d974203'}]
abstract: The states of several technologies are reviewed which are critical to the design of an aeroassisted orbital transfer vehicle. In these technologies, advancements are needed which hinge on obtaining new flight data. While some of the work can be done with the wind tunnel and computational disciplines, much of the required new data are tied to finite chemical reaction rates, possible thermal nonequilibrium, high flow enthalpy, and strong viscous effects. Because these effects cannot be modeled adequately in ground-based facilities, computational methods lack adequate verification to allow committing to the design of an aeroassist vehicle. Thus a new flight experiment is being planned by NASA to gather the required data. The flight experiment and associated instrumentation which NASA is proposing is discussed briefly.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

title: Experimental study of shock wave interference heating on a cylindrical leading edge at Mach 6 and 8
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055761, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Wieting, Allan R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'ec22eaf894b146d8818de82e4fd6e688'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055761, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Holden, Michael S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Calspan-University of Buffalo Research Center', 'location': 'New York, United States'}}, 'id': '344c0904f91f4af5b0f2b460384de710'}]
abstract: This paper presents the details of an experimental study of shock wave interference heating on a cylindrical leading edge representative of the cowl of a rectangular hypersonic engine inlet. The study was conducted at Mach numbers of 6.3, 6.5 and 8.0. This study has provided the first (1) detailed pressure and heat transfer rate distributions for a two-dimensional shock wave interference on a cylinder and (2) insight into the effects of temperature dependent specific heats on the phenomena. The peak pressure and heat transfer rates were 10 times the undisturbed flow stagnation point levels. The peak levels and their gradients increased with Mach number. Variation in specific heats and hence the ratio of specific heats with temperature manifest in slightly lower loads and amplification factors than for corresponding perfect gas conditions.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: This paper presents the details of an experimental study of shock wave interference heating on a cylindrical leading edge representative of a rectangular hypersonic engine inlet . The peak pressure and heat transfer rates were 10 times the undisturbed flow stagnation point levels . title: Interaction of transient radiation in fully developed laminar flows
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055771, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Tiwari, S. N.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Old Dominion Univ.', 'location': 'Norfolk, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '1973da2afc894a7da98afd44e55d60cb'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055771, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Singh, D. J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Old Dominion University', 'location': 'Norfolk, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'b500ab710cc8489ebd455312d624fa2f'}]
abstract: The transient radiative interactions of nongray absorbing-emitting species in laminar fully-developed flows between two parallel plates are investigated analytically and numerically. The particular species considered are OH, CO, CO2, and H2O and different mixtures of these species. Transient and steady-state results are obtained for the temperature distribution and bulk temperature for different plate spacings, wall temperatures, and pressures. Results, in general, indicate that the rate of radiative heating can be quite high during earlier times. This information is useful in designing thermal protection systems for transient operations.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The transient radiative interactions of nongray absorbing-emitting species in laminar flows between two parallel plates are investigated analytically and numerically . The particular species considered are OH, CO, CO2, and H2O and different mixtures of these species . Results indicate that the rate of radiative heating can be quite high during earlier times .

title: Combined conduction and radiation heat transfer in concentric cylindrical media
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055773, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Pandey, D. K.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Information and Control Systems, Inc.', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'dcd3fc5074724eb8ac639fc1ab2fa87c'}]
abstract: The exact radiative transfer expressions for gray and nongray gases which are absorbing, emitting and nonscattering, contained between infinitely long concentric cylinders with black surfaces, are given in local thermodynamic equilibrium. Resulting energy equations due to the combination of conduction and radiation modes of heat transfer, under steady state conditions for gray and nongray media, are solved numerically using the undetermined parameters method. A single 4.3-micron band of CO2 is considered for the nongray problems. The present solutions for gray and nongray gases obtained in the plane-parallel limit (radius ratio approaches to one) are compared with the plane-parallel results reported in the literature.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The exact radiative transfer expressions for gray and nongray gases which are absorbing, emitting and nonscattering, contained between infinitely long concentric cylinders with black surfaces, are given in local thermodynamic equilibrium . Resulting energy equations due to the combination of conduction and radiation modes of heat transfer are solved numerically using the undetermined parameters method .

title: Extension of a semi-implicit shock-capturing algorithm for 3-D fully coupled, chemically reacting flows in generalized coordinates
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055812, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Shinn, J. L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Langley Research Center', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': 'a949324cd7834415951cca6cb1e9b5f1'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055812, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Yee, H. C.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'ebbb31b010714f249435955a4016916a'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870055812, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Uenishi, K.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Vigyan Research Associates, Inc.', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '4144f0fac371495b95b51a86517ef29f'}]
abstract: A semiimplicit high-resolution shock-capturing method for multidimensional systems of hyperbolic conservation laws with stiff source terms has been developed by Yee and Shinn (1987). The goal of this work is to extend this method to solve the three-dimensional fully coupled Navier-Stokes equations for a hypersonic chemically reacting flow in generalized coordinates. In this formulation, the global continuity equation was replaced by all the species continuity equations. The shock-capturing technique is a second-order-accurate, symmetric total-variation-diminishing method which accounts fully and directly for the coupling among the fluid and all the species. To verify the current approach, it was implemented into an existing computer code which contained the MacCormack method. Test results for a five-species reacting flow are shown to be oscillation-free around the shock, and the time spent per iteration only doubles when compared to the result using classical way of supplying numerical dissipation. The extra computation is more than justified by the elimination of spurious oscillation and nonlinear instability associated with the classical shock-capturing schemes in computing hypersonic reacting flows.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A semiimplicit high-resolution shock-capturing method for multidimensional systems of hyperbolic conservation laws with stiff source terms has been developed by Yee and Shinn (1987) The goal of this work is to extend this method to solve the three-dimensional fully coupled Navier-Stokes equations for a hypersonic chemically reacting flow in generalized coordinates .

title: Effects of forced and free convections on structural temperatures of Space Shuttle Orbiter during reentry flight
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055830, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Ko, William L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Flight Research Center', 'location': 'Edwards, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'd32c1d98a12f47acbc5f1ab4f7269976'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055830, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Quinn, Robert D.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Flight Research Center', 'location': 'Edwards, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'eb91a5b1c83c45828dd19081f2de3784'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870055830, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Gong, Leslie'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Flight Research Center', 'location': 'Edwards, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '5cd7af5e18434dd5a08f6f3b2a34c08f'}]
abstract: Structural performance and resizing (SPAR) finite-element thermal analysis computer program was used in the heat transfer analysis of the Space Shuttle Orbiter wing subjected to reentry aerodynamic heating. With sufficient external forced convective cooling near the end of the heating cycle, the calculated surface temperatures of the thermal protection system (TPS) agree favorably with the flight data for the entire flight profile. However, the effects of this external forced convective cooling on the structural temperatures were found to be negligible. Both free convection and forced convection elements were introduced to model the internal convection effect of the cool air entering the Shuttle interior. The introduction of the internal free convection effect decreased the calculated wing lower skin temperatures by 20 F at most, 1200 sec after touchdown. If the internal convection is treated as forced convection, the calculated wing lower skin temperatures after touchdown can be reduced to match the flight-measured data very closely. By reducing the TPS thicknesses to certain effective thickness to account for the TPs gap heating, the calculated wing lower skin temperatures prior to touchdown can be raised to agree with the flight data perfectly.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Structural performance and resizing (SPAR) finite-element thermal analysis computer program was used in the heat transfer analysis of the Space Shuttle Orbiter wing subjected to reentry aerodynamic heating . With sufficient external forced convective cooling near the end of the heating cycle, the calculated surface temperatures of the thermal protection system agree favorably with the flight data .

title: Flow field description of the Space Shuttle Vernier reaction control system exhaust plumes
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055836, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Cerimele, Mary P.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'f43d4c5ebfdc4d6ca422a18d0c65f2de'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055836, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Alred, John W.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Johnson Space Center', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': '9b666975c7a14034b99c2c32b7704271'}]
abstract: The flow field for the Vernier Reaction Control System (VRCS) jets of the Space Shuttle Orbiter has been calculated from the nozzle throat to the far-field region. The calculations involved the use of recently improved rocket engine nozzle/plume codes. The flow field is discussed, and a brief overview of the calculation techniques is presented. In addition, a proposed on-orbit plume measurement experiment, designed to improve future estimations of the Vernier flow field, is addressed.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Flow field for the Vernier Reaction Control System (VRCS) jets of the Space Shuttle Orbiter has been calculated from the nozzle throat to the far-field region . The calculations involved the use of recently improved rocket engine nozzle/plume codes . The flow field is discussed, and a brief overview of the calculation techniques is presented .

title: Verification of an analytic modeler for capillary pump loop thermal control systems
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055853, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Schweickart, R. B.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': 'ee1f97e6684449488e5284cef49fd789'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055853, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Neiswanger, L.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': 'c149263a368444adba778b5bf322e736'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870055853, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Ku, J.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'OAO Corp.', 'location': 'Greenbelt, MD, United States'}}, 'id': '0172ff6d968e47399f4b53239bd47337'}]
abstract: A number of computer programs have been written to model two-phase heat transfer systems for space use. These programs support the design of thermal control systems and provide a method of predicting their performance in the wide range of thermal environments of space. Predicting the performance of one such system known as the capillary pump loop (CPL) is the intent of the CPL Modeler. By modeling two developed CPL systems and comparing the results with actual test data, the CPL Modeler has proven useful in simulating CPL operation. Results of the modeling effort are discussed, together with plans for refinements to the modeler.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Computer programs have been written to model two-phase heat transfer systems for space use . The CPL Modeler has proven useful in simulating CPL operation . Results of the modeling effort are discussed, together with plans for refinements to the modeler . The modeler is designed to simulate the performance of the capillary pump loop (CPL)

title: High temperature transport properties of air
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055855, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Levin, E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '4bbcf551026f4f7b80542efd70ee4dec'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055855, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Partridge, Harry'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '248ee0bef6d6420da06179b42cb3e3f5'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870055855, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Stallcop, J. R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'e5175cc06542484aac7336a9d818fa36'}]
abstract: A general computer code was developed to allow calculation of atom-atom and ion-atom transport collision integrals from accurate potential energy curves described by a set of discrete data points for a broad range of scattering conditions. This code is based upon semiclassical approximations that properly account for quantum mechanical behavior such as tunneling effects near a barrier maximum, resonance charge exchange, and nuclear symmetry effects. Transport collision integrals were determined for N-N, O-O, N(+)-N, and O(+)-O interactions from complete sets of accurate potential functions derived from combined experimental and ab initio structure calculations. For the O-O case, this includes results for excited states. The calculated values of the N(+)-N and O(+)-O resonance charge exchange cross section Q(ex) agree well with measurements from beam experiment that are available at high energies where the diffusion cross section Q(d) satisfies Q(d) approximately equal to 2Q(ex).
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A general computer code was developed to allow calculation of atom-atom and ion-atom transport collision collision integrals . This code is based upon semiclassical approximations that properly account for quantum mechanical behavior such as tunneling effects near a barrier maximum, resonance charge exchange, and nuclear symmetry effects .

title: Potential application of multipolarization SAR for pine-plantation biomass estimation
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055989, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Wu, Shih-Tseng'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA National Space Technology Laboratories', 'location': 'Bay Saint Louis, MS, United States'}}, 'id': '617c012f3c574b1799143c0bdcc0875c'}]
publications: [{'volume': 'GE-25', 'submissionId': 19870055989, 'issn': '0196-2892', 'id': '38c13ce9266647e7b9ba16b3d7296def', 'publicationName': 'IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing', 'publicationDate': '1987-05-01T00:00:00.0000000+00:00'}]
abstract: This paper presents the technique and the potential utility of multipolarization Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data for pine-plantation biomass estimation. Three channels of SAR data, one from the Shuttle Imaging Radar SIR-A and the other two from the aircraft SAR, were acquired over the Baldwin County, Alabama, study area. The SIR-A data were acquired with HH polarization and the aircraft SAR data with VV and VH polarizations. Linear regression techniques are used to estimate the pine-plantation biomass, tree height, and age using 21 test plots. The results indicate that the multipolarization data are highly related to the plantation biomass. The results suggest a potential application of multipolarization SAR for pine-plantation biomass estimation.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: This paper presents the technique and the potential utility of multipolarization Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data for pine-plantation biomass estimation . Three channels of SAR data, one from the Shuttle Imaging Radar SIR-A and the other two from the aircraft SAR, were acquired over the Baldwin County, Alabama, study area .

title: The onset of Alfvenic turbulence
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870055998, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Ghosh, S.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Goddard Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Greenbelt; Maryland, University, College Park, United States'}}, 'id': '982cfffb5bfa4b6aad1afdceee48f462'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870055998, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Papadopoulos, K.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Maryland, University', 'location': 'College Park, United States'}}, 'id': 'b0c499112aec4b05852fb695e25d138c'}]
abstract: An investigation is conducted on how low-frequency MHD oscillations in a warm plasma may undergo a transition from a coherent state to one of turbulence. A driven/dissipative derivative nonlinear Schroedinger equation is derived from the fluid equations. The time evolution of an arbitrary spectrum of waves is analyzed in the case where one k-mode is unstable, with the rest damped. It is found that the transition from order to chaos in the driven/dissipative system is correlated with the existence or absence of 'breathing' solitons in the associated conservative system.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: An investigation is conducted on how low-frequency MHD oscillations in a warm plasma may undergo a transition from a coherent state to one of turbulence . title: Tidal influences on vertical diffusion and diurnal variability of ozone in the mesosphere
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056093, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Bjarnason, Gudmundur G.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences', 'location': 'Boulder, CO, United States'}}, 'id': 'c756e26a173c4ce592b80bd9169d2fdc'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870056093, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Solomon, Susan'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NOAA, Aeronomy Laboratory, Boulder', 'location': 'CO, United States'}}, 'id': '4dd7b59d6e3a4769a46e2667e23516f8'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870056093, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Garcia, Rolando R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'National Center for Atmospheric Research', 'location': 'Boulder, CO, United States'}}, 'id': '2cf606fee1cc40629824180761ce1d89'}]
abstract: Possible dynamical influences on the diurnal behavior of ozone are investigated. A time dependent one-dimensional photochemical model is developed for this purpose; all model calculations are made at 70 deg N during summer. It is shown that the vertical diffusion can vary as much as 1 order of magnitude within a day as a result of large changes in the zonal wind induced by atmospheric thermal tides. It is found that by introducing a dissipation time scale for turbulence produced by breaking gravity waves, the agreement with Poker Flat echo data is improved. Comparisons of results from photochemical model calculations, where the vertical diffusion is a function of height only, with those in which the vertical diffusion coefficient is changing in time show large differences in the diurnal behavior of ozone between 70 and 90 km. By including the dynamical effect, much better agreement with the Solar Mesosphere Explorers data is obtained. The results are, however, sensitive to the background zonally averaged wind. The influence of including time-varying vertical diffusion coefficient on the OH densities is also large, especially between 80 and 90 km. This suggests that dynamical effects are important in determining the diurnal behavior of the airglow emission from the Meinel bands.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Possible dynamical influences on the diurnal behavior of ozone are investigated . A time dependent one-dimensional photochemical model is developed for this purpose . The vertical diffusion can vary as much as 1 order of magnitude within a day as a result of large changes in the zonal wind induced by atmospheric thermal tides .

title: Advances and trends in computational structural mechanics
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056113, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Noor, Ahmed K.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'George Washington University', 'location': 'Hampton, VA, United States'}}, 'id': '2e2b7c75d4b44dc3a72042c0522bbfec'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870056113, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Atluri, Satya N.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Georgia Institute of Technology', 'location': 'Atlanta, United States'}}, 'id': '9103ef4920234d3794468f1ff213db51'}]
abstract: The development status and applicational range of techniques in computational structural mechanics (CSM) are evaluated with a view to advances in computational models for material behavior, discrete-element technology, quality assessment, the control of numerical simulations of structural response, hybrid analysis techniques, techniques for large-scale optimization, and the impact of new computing systems on CSM. Primary pacers of CSM development encompass prediction and analysis of novel materials for structural components, computational strategies for large-scale structural calculations, and the assessment of response prediction reliability together with its adaptive improvement.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The development status and applicational range of techniques in computational structural mechanics (CSM) are evaluated with a view to advances in computational models for material behavior, discrete-element technology, quality assessment, and new computing systems on CSM . Primary pacers of CSM development encompass prediction and analysis of novel materials for structural components .

title: Measurement of side forces of a H-force rotor
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056136, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Velkoff, Henry R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center; U.S. Army, Advanced Research Technology Activity, Moffett Field', 'location': 'CA, United States'}}, 'id': 'dd88fb53b067498c9508ff5736557d71'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870056136, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Petersilge, Christian'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Ames Research Center', 'location': 'Moffett Field, CA, United States'}}, 'id': '1badab7fe2a34fabaf9685ef5956f468'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870056136, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Cowan, Curtis'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Ohio State University', 'location': 'Columbus, United States'}}, 'id': '43e245a0b92f49b79aeeffa640b43cc3'}]
abstract: Study of the use of tip vanes has been underway to investigate both the impact of the vanes on hover performance and on their potential use as force generators. It is the aim of this paper to report on progress made to determine the forces that can be generated. Model tests were run using a 6-ft-diameter rotor with tip vanes pivoted below the blade tips. Data were taken on the thrust, torque, and side force. The results obtained were in substantial agreement with the side force predicted by using a simple wing model.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Model tests were run using a 6-ft-diameter rotor with tip vanes pivoted below the blade tips . Data were taken on thrust, torque, and side force . Results obtained were in substantial agreement with the side force predicted by using a simple wing model .

title: Stability and control modelling
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056154, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Curtiss, H. C., Jr.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Princeton University', 'location': 'NJ, United States'}}, 'id': '5a0110735a5d440b8a0c5584dde67734'}]
abstract: This paper discusses the influence of rotor dynamics and dynamic inflow on the stability and control characteristics of single rotor helicopters in near hovering flight. Body attitude and rate feedback gain limitations which arise due to rotor dynamics and dynamic inflow are discussed. It is shown that attitude feedback gain is limited primarily by body-flap coupling and rate gain is limited by the lag degrees of freedom. Dynamic inflow is shown to produce significant changes in the modes of motion.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: This paper discusses the influence of rotor dynamics and dynamic inflow on stability and control characteristics of single rotor helicopters in near hovering flight . It is shown that attitude feedback gain is limited primarily by body-flap coupling . Dynamic inflow is shown to produce significant changes in the modes of motion .

title: The relationship between geology and geochemistry in the Undarum/Spumans/Balmer region of the moon
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056421, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Clark, P. E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'California Institute of Technology', 'location': 'Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, United States'}}, 'id': 'ff4dfc3af0464f6e92bc1c19e54645f8'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870056421, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Hawke, B. R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Hawaii, University', 'location': 'Honolulu, United States'}}, 'id': 'a9c3e4243d334c91971cc9a472905d40'}]
abstract: Based on regional maps of orbital geochemical variables, major geochemical heterogeneities in the Undarum/Sumans/Balmer region of the moon are found which are usually associated with distinct geological features, and which reveal a north/south dichotomy. The mapped mare and plains units are often the site of heterogeneity, and the plains units in the Balmer basin are probably composed of volcanic material, possibly KREEP-enriched basalt. Data suggest that the northeastern part of the region may contain a minor spinel component. Major mare units of the region are found to have two distinct compositions, possibly indicating two different source regions for the basalts deposited there, but more likely indicating contamination with different amounts of highland debris.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

The mapped mare and plains units are often the site of heterogeneity, and the plains units in the Balmer basin are probably composed of volcanic material . title: Implications of lithospheric bending and faulting in lunar mare-terra tectonics
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056423, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Raitala, Jouko'}, 'organization': {'name': 'California Institute of Technology', 'location': 'Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, United States'}}, 'id': '4ddbea534eb24e3f9b62dea38887a046'}]
abstract: A qualitative model of lithospheric flexure and faulting is proposed which accounts for certain rille fault features around mare regions of the moon. It is suggested that the subsidence of lunar mare basins may be due to the existence of their mascons and their volcanic fills as loads that flexed the lithosphere, in addition to the effects of drying up and cooling of internal hot volumes. Differences in the internal attack against the lunar crust from above and below the mean surface are considered. The rille formation is shown to be characterized by peripheral bulging and bending, and it is suggested that asthenosphere-related effects in lunar tectonics may have been very important.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: A qualitative model of lithospheric flexure and faulting is proposed which accounts for certain rille fault features around mare regions of the moon . It is suggested that the subsidence of lunar mare basins may be due to the existence of their mascons and their volcanic fills as loads that flexed the lithosphere .

title: Collisional evolution of rotating, non-identical particles
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056424, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Salo, H.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'California Institute of Technology', 'location': 'Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, United States'}}, 'id': '7bb65f8e451242d18f6f100ad4aa3edb'}]
abstract: Hameen-Anttila's (1984) theory of self-gravitating collisional particle disks is extended to include the effects of particle spin. Equations are derived for the coupled evolution of random velocities and spins, showing that friction and surface irregularity both reduce the local velocity dispersion and transfer significant amounts of random kinetic energy to rotational energy. Results for the equilibrium ratio of rotational energy to random kinetic energy are exact not only for identical nongravitating mass points, but also if finite size, self-gravitating forces, or size distribution are included. The model is applied to the dynamics of Saturn's rings, showing that the inclusion of rotation reduces the geometrical thickness of the layer of cm-sized particles to, at most, about one-half, with large particles being less affected.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Hameen-Anttila's (1984) theory of self-gravitating collisional particle disks is extended to include the effects of particle spin . Equations are derived for the coupled evolution of random velocities and spins . The model is applied to the dynamics of Saturn's rings, showing that the inclusion of rotation reduces the geometrical thickness of the layer of cm-sized particles to about one-half .

title: Observations and theory of the AMPTE magnetotail barium releases
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056457, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Bernhardt, P. A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Los Alamos National Lab.', 'location': 'NM, United States'}}, 'id': 'ce345d3c966e4d68a76e6cd993b4dd02'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870056457, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Roussel-Dupre, R. A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Los Alamos National Lab.', 'location': 'NM, United States'}}, 'id': '3f6bf21186a6471b953274438e9212db'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870056457, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Pongratz, M. B.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Los Alamos National Laboratory', 'location': 'NM, United States'}}, 'id': '976c05220073460680bb3daab2be821c'}, {'sequence': 3, 'submissionId': 19870056457, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Haerendel, G.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Los Alamos National Lab.', 'location': 'NM, United States'}}, 'id': 'db63d7ef717f4a2ba790b780cc00cc20'}, {'sequence': 4, 'submissionId': 19870056457, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Valenzuela, A.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik', 'location': 'Garching, Germany'}}, 'id': 'b07ecb88624d4800bda03310ff2911f6'}]
abstract: The barium releases in the magnetotail during the Active Magnetospheric Particle Tracer Explorers (AMPTE) operation were monitored by ground-based imagers and by instruments on the Ion Release Module. After each release, the data show the formation of a structured diamagnetic cavity. The cavity grows until the dynamic pressure of the expanding ions balances the magnetic pressure on its surface. The magnetic field inside the cavity is zero. The barium ions collect on the surface of the cavity, producing a shell. Plasma irregularities form along magnetic field lines draped over the surface of the cavity. The scale size of the irregularities is nearly equal to the thickness of the shell. The evolution and structuring of the diamagnetic cavity are modeled using magnetohydrodynamics theory.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: Barium releases in the magnetotail during the Active Magnetospheric Particle Tracer Explorers (AMPTE) operation were monitored by ground-based imagers and by instruments on the Ion Release Module . After each release, the data show the formation of a structured diamagnetic cavity .

title: The ionosphere as a fully adequate source of plasma for the earth's magnetosphere
authorAffiliations: [{'sequence': 0, 'submissionId': 19870056467, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Chappell, C. R.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Marshall Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Huntsville, AL, United States'}}, 'id': 'cc72f0652fd5487e8253fd433f924de4'}, {'sequence': 1, 'submissionId': 19870056467, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Moore, T. E.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Marshall Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Huntsville, AL, United States'}}, 'id': '021bb7b3f79049729a01f61b237317e0'}, {'sequence': 2, 'submissionId': 19870056467, 'meta': {'author': {'name': 'Waite, J. H., Jr.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'NASA Marshall Space Flight Center', 'location': 'Huntsville, AL, United States'}}, 'id': '3de2f9741f3548e6af48d29331ce5a65'}]
abstract: The ionospheric contribution of the polar wind and cleft ion fountain at energies less than 10 eV has been added to previously measured sources; this total ion outflow has then been used to calculate the resulting ion density in the different internal regions of the earth's magnetosphere: plasmasphere, plasma trough, plasma sheet, and magnetotail lobes. Using estimated volumes for these regions and an ion residence time characteristic of each region, it is found that the observed magnetospheric densities can be attained in all cases with no contribution from the solar wind plasma. In the case of the plasma sheet the ionospherically supplied density is more than enough to match the observations and even suggests an invisible component of low-energy plasma (less than 10 eV) which has never been observed. A detailed comparison between the calculated ionospheric source effects in the plasma sheet and those recently measured by ISEE shows excellent agreement and suggests a direct polar low-energy ion source for the plasma sheet which has remained unmeasured because of spacecraft potential effects. Although the solar wind is clearly the earth's magnetospheric energy source and energetic solar wind ions are observed in the magnetosphere, these calculations suggest the possibility that the ionospheric source alone is sufficient to supply the entire magnetospheric plasma content under all geomagnetic conditions.
center.name: Legacy CDMS
summary: The ionospheric contribution of the polar wind and cleft ion fountain at energies less than 10 eV has been added to previously measured sources . This total ion outflow has been used to calculate the resulting ion density in the different internal regions of the earth's magnetosphere: plasmasphere, plasma trough, plasma sheet, and magnetotail lobes .

title: Differential cross sections for scattering of 0.5-, 1.5-, and 5.0 keV oxygen atoms by He, N2, and O2

F.'}, 'organization': {'name': 'Rice University', 'location': 'Houston, TX, United States'}}, 'id': 'c333fb78b65248c9b704592cfcaace4a'}]
abstract: This paper reports measurements of absolute scattering cross sections, differential in angle, for collisions of ground-state oxygen atoms with He, N2, and O2. Data are presented for scattering of 0.5-, 1.5-, and 5.0-keV oxygen-atom projectiles in the range of laboratory frame angles between 0.06 and 5 deg. These measurements provide information relevant to calculations of the aeronomic consequences of O(+) precipitation in the earth's upper atmosphere.
center.name: Legacy CDMS

These measurements provide information relevant to calculations of the aeronomic consequences of O(+) precipitation in the earth's upper atmosphere .
